content:
re: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/76272

Obvious options

  1. always run CI on drafts (current)
  2. never run CI on drafts (with that PR)
  3. opt-out CI on drafts (proposed by https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/76272#issuecomment-686600591)
  4. opt-in CI on drafts (proposed by https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/67357#issuecomment-566252404)

additionally: Regardless, probably review the rules for rust-log-analyzer and such?

I am more-or-less fine with Always and Never because I think either rule is... principled? About Opt In or Opt Out, honestly thinking about it a bit longer I would be against Opt In, as it would become Another Thing To Learn on the most forward-facing element of contributing, so it works more against people the newer they are. Inconsistencies should generally run the other direction.
there's also the fact that marking it 'draft' is in itself an opt-in
if you want people to see it's a draft but not machines, you can add [WIP] or something
I am still not seeing benefits to changing anything here personally - seems like CI running can only help folks out. I wouldn't want to complicate our configuration for this I think.
Any decision resolves the issue, so that Would Also Be Fine. :musical_notes:
I think running it always but turning RLA off could be a good compromise

i was wondering, if we should defer on assigning reviewers to draft prs. Maybe have highfive assign a reviewer only when a pr is converted from draft -> ready. Or at least label it as s-waiting-on-author till a draft pr is marked as ready
